introduction.p: You may save your work at any time by clicking on Save. When you are finished working, click on Submit and Finish, a pop up window will ask "This will submit your answers and finish this assignment. Are you sure?", click "OK" if you are ready to submit your answers for final grading.
If you close this window without having saved or submitted, your changes will be lost. After pressing Submit and Finish, please wait for your answers to be scored. Do NOT click on it more than once.

body.p: Where does the process of digestion begin in your body?

feedback.p: Correct. Both chemical and physical digestion begins in the mouth.
Incorrect. No digestion occurs in the esophagus.
Incorrect. The stomach continues the digestion that began in the mouth.
Incorrect. The small intestine continues digestion but does not begin the process.

body.p: Which of the following is not properly matched with its level of organization?

feedback.p: Correct. Enzymes are a type of protein and are macromolecules not small enough to be on the chemical level.
Incorrect. Secretory cells are a type of cell and are classified on the cell level.
Incorrect. The pancreas is an organ of the digestive system.
Incorrect. The GI tract involves the integration of several digestive organs.

body.p: Which of the following accurately describes breakdown of food into molecules that can be absorbed?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although hydrolysis can occur spontaneously this would be too slow for the process of digestion.
Correct. Hydrolysis catalyzed by enzymes allows food to be broken down fast enough for digestion to occur.
Incorrect. Dehydration synthesis is the process of removing water to make molecules bigger not smaller.
Incorrect. Dehydration synthesis is the process of removing water to make molecules bigger not smaller.

body.p: Which of the following is the correct order of the digestion of starch?

input.choice: Pancreatic amylase begins the breakdown of starch, which continues with salivary amylase and completes with a-dextrinase breaking down a-dextrin into fructose
Salivary amylase begins the breakdown of starch, which continues with pancreatic amylase and completes with a-dextrinase breaking down a-dextrin into glucose
Salivary amylase begins the breakdown of starch, which continues with pancreatic amylase and completes with a-dextrinase breaking down a-dextrin into glucose
Pancreatic amylase begins the breakdown of starch, which continues with salivary amylase and completes with a-dextrinase breking down a-dextrin into glucose

feedback.p: Incorrect. Amylase is named after the location that is producing it. Pancreatic amylase continues the digestion of starch started by the salivary amylase produced in the mouth.
Correct. This is the proper sequence of events. Salivary amylase begins digestion of starch, the pancreatic amylase continues this digestion and a-dextrinase completes the digestion to glucose.

Incorrect. This is the proper sequence of events. Salivary amylase begins digestion of starch, the pancreatic amylase continues this digestion and a-dextrinase completes the digestion to glucose. Starch is made of glucose not fructose.
Incorrect. Amylase is named after the location that is producing it. Pancreatic amylase continues the digestion of starch started by the salivary amylase produced in the mouth.

body.p: Which of the following enzymes is not matched properly with its function?

input.choice: Pepsin breaks down proteins into peptides.
Trypsin hydrolyze polypeptides into smaller peptides.

feedback.p: Correct. Carboxypeptisase cleaves an entire amino acid from the carboxy terminus of a polypeptide not just a carbon atom.Incorrect. Pepsin does break complex proteins down into simpler peptides.
Incorrect. Pepsin does break complex proteins down into simpler peptides.
Incorrect. Trypsin does break down polypeptides into smaller peptides.
Incorrect. As its name suggestions dipeptidase splits a dipeptide into two single amino acids.

body.p: Which of these is not involved in the chemical digestion of proteins?

feedback.p: Correct. Pancreatic amylase is involved in the chemical digestion of starch not proteins.
Incorrect. Trypsin is an enzyme that hydrolyses proteins.
Incorrect. Carboxypeptidase is an enzyme that hydrolyses peptides.
Incorrect. Amionopeptidase is an enzyme that hydrolyses peptides

body.p: What is the benefit of emulsifying lipids with bile salts?

input.choice: It decreases the hydrophilic nature of the lipid.
It increases the surface area so pancreatic lipase can digest it easier.
The bile salts digest the lipid into fatty acids and monoglycerides
The bile salts separate the lipids into saturated and unsaturated fats.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Lipids are hydrophobic which is why they are hard to digest in the watery environment of the small intestine.
Correct. By increasing the surface area emulsification allows the enzyme to access more of the lipid.
Incorrect. The bile salts help break up large globules of lipids into smaller globules with more surface area so that enzymes can digest them more efficiently.
Incorrect. The bile salts help breakd up large globules of lipids into smaller globules but they are not able to separate them into chemically different fats.

body.p: Where are most fat-digesting enzymes produced?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The small intestine uses lipases produced by the pancreas to digest fat so that the brush boarder enzymes can work on it.
Incorrect. Chemical digestion of fats by enzyme begins in the stomach, but the pancreas produces more.
Incorrect. The liver produces bile which helps emulsify fats but is not an enzyme.
Correct. The pancreas produce pancreatic lipase which travels to the small intestine.

body.p: What three things do nucleosidases and phosphatase break nucleotides up into?

input.choice: pentose sugars, phosphates and nitrogenous bases
pentose sugars, phosphates and sulfuric bases
hexose sugars, phosphates and nitrogenous bases
hexose sugars, phosphates and sulfuric bases

feedback.p: Correct. Nucleotides are made out of three main parts, a pentose (5 carbon) sugar, phosphate and a nitrogenous base. Nucleosidaes are enzymes that digest nucleotides into their three component parts.
Incorrect. Nucleotides do not contain sulfur. It is an element that is found in proteins not nucleic acids.
Incorrect. Nucleotides have 5 carbon sugars or pentose. Monosaccarides like glucose have six carbon hexose.
Incorrect. Nucleotides have 5 carbon sugars or pentose. Monosaccarides like glucose have six carbon hexose. Also sulfur is found in proteins not nucleic acids.

body.p: Which of the following is not matched with the proper function:

input.choice: Phosphate ions- a buffer to prevent a change in pH
Urea- immune molecules that helps with pathogen clearance

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mucus helps to lubricate food to make it easier to swallow.
Incorrect. Phosphate ions act as a buffer to help maintain the pH of the mouth.
Incorrect. Chloride ions activate the salivary amylase so it can begin breaking down starch.
Correct. Urea is a waste product that is being eliminated through the saliva. Immunoglobuin A is an immune molecule located in the saliva

body.p: What does the HCl produced by the gastric glands assist in?

input.choice: Activating the intrinsic factor for the absorption of vitamin B 12
Activating pepsinogen into pepsin for protein digestion
Neutralizing the acidity of the gastric juice
Lowering the acidity by dissociating into H+ ions

feedback.p: Incorrect. Intrinsic factor is needed for the absorption of vitamin B 12 but it is not activated by HCl.
Correct. HCl lowers the pH of the stomach and allows pepsinogen to become the active enzyme pepsin.
Incorrect. HCl dissociates into hydrogen ions which lowers the pH and will not neutralize it.
Incorrect. HCl dissociates into H+ but this will increase the acidity. More H+ ions results in a more acidic environment.

body.p: What is the function of intrinsic factor?

input.choice: Protect the stomach lining from acid
Kill bacteria in the food we ingest
Assist in the absorption of vitamin B 12

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mucus protects the stomach lining from acid.
Incorrect. The HCl kills many of the bacteria in the food we ingest.
Correct. Intrinsic factor is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B 12 .
Incorrect. Pepsin is the enzyme involved in breaking down protein.

body.p: Which of these statements about gastric secretions is not true?

input.choice: Hydrochloric acid helps to digest protein
Pepsinogen is the inactive form of pepsin
Intrinsic factor is necessary for the absorption of vitamin D

feedback.p: Incorrect. Hydrochloric acid helps to denature proteins and helps the digestion of proteins.
Incorrect. Pepsinogen is an inactive form of pepsin that is activated by a low pH.
Correct. Intrinsic factor is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 not vitamin D.
Incorrect. Gastrin does promote gastric emptying.

body.p: What can occur if there is a breakdown of the stomach mucosa?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Diarrhea is a result of extra water being excreted and not absorbed in the large intestine.
Incorrect. Heart burn can result from the stomach acid moving up the esophagus, not burning through the mucus membrane.
Correct. Ulcers can result from a failure of the mucosa to block the acid.
Incorrect. Hemorrhoids are inflamed veins.

body.p: In addition to emulsifying fats, bile salts also assist in what activity?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Bicarbonate ions assist in neutralizing stomach acid.
Incorrect. Mechanical mixing is accomplished by the muscles of the stomach.
Incorrect. Pepsin is responsible for digesting proteins.
Correct. Bile salts are also involved in the absorption of the digested lipids.

body.p: Which is the correct order of activation of the zymogens?

input.choice: Enteropeptidase activates procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase which activates trypsinogen to trypsin.
Enteropeptidase activates trypsinogen to trypsin which activates procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase.
Enteropeptidase activates chymotrypsin which in turn activates trypsinogen to trypsin.
Enteropeptidase activates trypsin to trypsinogen which activates procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Procarboxypeptisase is activated by trypsin.
Correct. This is the order of zymogens.
Incorrect. Chymotrypsin is an active form of the zymogen procarboxypeptisase and is activated by trypsin.
Incorrect. Trypsin is the active form of trypsinogen.

body.p: Chief cells secrete which two substances?

feedback.p: Correct. Chief cells secrete lipase and pepsinogen which can be activated to pepsin.
Incorrect. Pepsin is the activate form of pepsinogen and HCl is secreted by the parietal cells.
Incorrect. Lipase is secreted by the chief cells but HCl is secreted by the parietal cells.
Incorrect. HCl and intrinsic factor are secreted by the parietal cells.

body.p: Which of these cells secrete hormone signaling molecules?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Parietal cells secrete HCl and intrinsic factor which are not hormones.
Incorrect. Mucosal cells of the gastric glands secrete protective mucus.
Incorrect. Chief cells secrete pepsin and gastric lipase which are digestive enzymes not hormones.
Correct. G-Cells secrete gastin which is a hormone that signals stomach motility promotes gastric emptying.

body.p: Kupffer cells are:

input.choice: Found in the sinusoids between laminae
Found in blood filled spaces between laminae
Phagocytic cells that remove foreign material
All of the above are correct

feedback.p: Partially correct. Kupffer cells are found in sinusoids between laminae but this is the name for the blood filled spaces so options A and B are the same
Partially correct. Kupffer cells are found in sinusoids between laminae but this is the name for the blood filled spaces so options A and B are the same
Partially correct. Kupffer cells are phagocytic and can eat dead cells and foreign material but they are also located in the sinusoids between laminae.
Correct. A and B state the same thing in different ways and C is a correct description of the kupffer cells functions.

body.p: Which of the following best describes endocrine cells of the pancreas?

input.choice: Are located in clusters called islets
Both B and C are correct.

feedback.p: Incorrect. 99% of the pancreas cells are acini cells that secrete pancreatic juice.
Partially correct. Endocrine cells are clustered into islets but they also only make up a small percentage of the pancreas.
Partially correct. Endocrine cells do make up only a small percentage of the pancreas but they also are clustered.
Correct. The endocrine cells of the pancreas are clustered into islets and only account for 1% of the cells in the pancreas.

body.p: If too little cholecystokinin is produced, what could be the result?

input.choice: An abnormal change in insulin levels
A lack of digestive enzyme release
An increase in the alkalinity of the small intestine
A decrease in the acidity of the small intestine

feedback.p: Incorrect. Gastric inhibitory peptide influences insulin levels.
Correct. Cholecystokinin stimulates the release of digestive enzymes from the pancreas and gall bladder.
Incorrect. This would be the result of too much secretin being produced.
Incorrect this would be the result of too little secretin being produced.

body.p: Why is mucus the only significant secretion of the large intestine?

input.choice: Because mucus plays an important role in the digestion that needs to occur in the large intestine.
Because mucus plays an important role in absorbing nutrients.
Because mucus plays an important role in producing vitamins B and K.
Because mucus plays an important role in lubricating digestive residue.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Most digestion has occurred before the large intestine.
Incorrect. Most nutrients have already been absorbed before the large intestine.
Incorrect. Bacteria residing in the large intestine produce vitamin B and K.
Correct. Most digestion and absorption has occurred before the large intestine the mucus plays an important role in helping the waste exit the body.

body.p: Which layer of the GI tract contains immune cells abbreviated MALT?

feedback.p: Correct. The MALT is lymph tissue that is found in the lamina propria of the mucosa.
Incorrect. The submucosa contains the submucosal plexus which is part of the nervous system control.
Incorrect. The musclaris contains muscle tissue that allows movement of food through the digestive system.
Incorrect. The serosa contains connective tissue and epithelial tissue but not immune cells of the MALT.

body.p: Which of the following is a function of the plicae, villi and microvilli?

input.choice: Increase surface area to increase absorption
House lymphatic capillaries to absorb fat

feedback.p: Incorrect. The MALT tissue has immune function not these three structures.
Incorrect. The brush border enzymes secreted by the cells of the mucosa are responsible for digesting carbohydrates and proteins.
Correct. All three of these structures increase the surface area of the small intestine and make absorption more efficient.
Incorrect. The villi are the structures that house the lymph capillaries called lacteal that absorb fat.

body.p: Which of the five major peritoneal folds provides a pathway for the blood supply of the liver and contains the common bile duct?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The greater omentum stores adipose tissue.
Incorrect. The falciform ligament attaches the liver to the anterior abdominal wall.
Correct. The lesser omentum provides a pathway for blood supply to the liver and the common bile duct. Remember that blood vessels cannot travel through empty space, there must be tissue around them.
Incorrect. The mesentery includes blood vessels and lymphatic tissue for the small intestine.

body.p: What term(s) are used to describe the continuous muscular tube that runs from the mouth to the anus?

input.choice: Accessory digestive organs and the gastrointestinal tract
Digestive system organs and alimentary canal

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although the term gut can be used to describe this tube, the accessory digestive organs lay outside of this tract.
Incorrect. Although the term gastrointestinal tract can be used to describe this tube, the accessory digestive organs lay outside of this tract.
Incorrect. Although the term alimentary canal can be used to describe this tube, the digestive system organs include the accessory digestive organs lay outside of this tract.
Correct. The alimentary canal refers to the idea of nourishment and the gastrointestinal tract describes the tract that includes stomach (gastro) and intestines (intestinal).

body.p: Which of the following structures is not involved in the chemical digestion of food?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The mouth contains salivary amylase which begins the breakdown of starch.
Incorrect. The stomach contains pepsin which begins the digestion of protein.
Incorrect. The small intestine contains many digestive enzymes from the pancreas and brush boarder enzymes that digest food.
Correct. The large intestine is not involved in the chemical digestion of food. The bacteria there can digest some residual food for their own nutrition.

body.p: What is the result of mastication?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Chyme is formed in the stomach after food has been mixed with gastric juice.
Incorrect. Feces are formed in the large intestine after excess water has been removed.
Incorrect. Fauces are the passage ways into your throat.
Correct. Mastication results in the formation of a bolus which is chewed food mixed with saliva.

body.p: Which of these processes does not occur in the mouth?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Ingestion, the intake of food, is one of the primary functions of the mouth.
Incorrect. Mechanical digestion through mastication is one of the primary functions of the mouth.
Incorrect. Chemical digestion of starch by salivary amylase is one of the primary functions of the mouth.
Correct. Absorption of nutrients primary takes place in the small intestine and does not occur at all in the mouth.

body.p: What is the function of the “dangling thing”( uvula) in the back of your throat?

input.choice: It plays a role in mastication.
It plays a role in speech.
It plays a role in the immune system.
It plays a role in chemical digestion.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The teeth, tongue, and cheeks play the major roles in mastication (chewing).
Correct. The uvula plays are role in speech and articulation as well as a small role in preventing foods and liquids from entering the nasal cavity.
Incorrect. The tonsils contain lymph tissue that has an immune function.
Incorrect. The saliva from the salivary glands plays a role in chemical digestion.

body.p: What is the function of the papillae?

input.choice: None of the above are the function of the papillae.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The papillae with taste buds can perform this function but the papillae without taste buds have a different function.
Incorrect. The papillae without taste buds can detect the texture of food, but the ones with taste buds function in taste.
Correct. The papillae with taste buds function in the sense of taste, the papillae without taste buds function in the sense of touch for texture.
Incorrect. Both of these are functions of different papillae of the tongue.

body.p: Damage to which salivary gland would have the least effect on the digestion of carbohydrates?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The parotid gland secretes a significant amount of salivary amylase that digests carbohydrates.
Incorrect. The submandibular glands contain produce thicker mucous then the parotid but still contains salivary amylase.
Correct. The sublingual cells contain mostly mucous secreting cells and so secrete a lot of mucous but not a lot of salivary amylase that digests carbohydrates.

body.p: Which of these glands secrete the least saliva?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The parotid glands are a pair of major salivary glands that secrete saliva.
Correct. The palatal glands secrete a small amount of saliva in response to the presence of food.
Incorrect. The submandibular glands secrete saliva with amylase that helps to break down carbohydrates.
Incorrect. Sublingual glands secrete the thickest saliva with the least amount of salivary amylase.

body.p: What is the hardest substance in the body?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The gingivae are the gums.
Correct. Enamel which covers the outside of the teeth is the hardest substance in the body.
Incorrect. Dentin is part of the tooth but is not has hard as the outer coating.
Incorrect. Although the minerals of bone make it hard, enamel is designed to resist chewing and acids in food.

body.p: Which division of the pharynx would you not expect to find food in?

input.choice: It would be common to find food in all of the divisions of the pharynx.

feedback.p: Correct. The nasopharynx is actually blocked off by the soft palate while swallowing to prevent food from going up into it.
Incorrect. The oropharynx connects anteriorly with the mouth and receives the bolus after mastication.
Incorrect. Muscles of the laryngopharynx help push the bolus into the esophagus.
Incorrect. The most superior division of the pharynx should not have food in it.

body.p: The part of the mouth that is bordered internally by the gums and teeth and externally by the cheeks and lips is called the what?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The oral cavity includes the entire area enclosed by the cheeks, tongue, hard palate, and soft palate.
Incorrect. The buccal cavity is the same as the oral cavity and includes the entire area enclosed by the cheeks, tongue, hard palate, and soft palate.
Correct. The oral vestibule is the area between the gums and teeth. If you puff out your cheeks you change the size of the oral vestibule.
Incorrect. The fauces are passages that are the entrance to the throat.

body.p: What is the function of the constrictor muscles?

input.choice: Cough to move food back out of the trachea
Sneeze to remove waste from the nasopharynx

feedback.p: Incorrect. Coughing involves the muscles of the chest.
Incorrect. The trachea or the windpipe receives air not food.
Correct. The constrictor muscles of the pharynx contract to propel food into the esophagus.
Incorrect. The constrictor muscles of the pharynx are not the primary muscles of sneezing.

body.p: Which structure is located where the esophagus penetrates the diaphragm?

feedback.p: Correct. The esophageal hiatus is the opening in the diaphragm through which the esophagus passes.
Incorrect. The cardiac orifice is the opening where the esophagus joins the stomach.
Incorrect. The upper esophageal sphincter regulates food movement from the pharynx to the esophagus.
Incorrect. The lower esophageal sphincter regulates food movement from the esophagus to the stomach.

body.p: Which of the following correctly describes the muscle contractions of peristalsis in the esophagus?

input.choice: Circular muscle layer superior to the bolus contracts pushing the bolus forward and the longitudinal muscle layer inferior contracts to receive the bolus.
The longitudinal muscle layer superior to the bolus contracts pushing the bolus forward and the circular muscle layer inferior also contracts to receive the bolus.
Circular muscle layer superior to the bolus contracts pushing the bolus forward and the longitudinal muscle layer inferior relaxes to receive the bolus.
Circular muscle layer superior to the bolus relaxes pushing the bolus forward and the longitudinal muscle layer inferior contracts to receive the bolus.

feedback.p: Correct. The circular layer of the muscularis and the longitudinal layer of the muscularis work together to create wave like contractions that propel the bolus forward towards the stomach.
Incorrect. Contraction of the circular layer would result in a narrowing of the esophagus which would inhibit the bolus from moving forward.
Incorrect. By relaxing the longitudinal muscle they would become shorter tightening the esophagus instead of opening it to receive the bolus.
Incorrect. Relaxation of the circular muscles would result in a widening of the esophagus behind the bolus and would not generate force to push it forward.

body.p: What structure controls stomach emptying into the duodenum?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The dome-shaped fundus is a region of the stomach that temporarily stores food but is not the specific structure that allows for expansion.
Correct. The pyloric sphincter controls chyme entering the duodenum
Incorrect. The greater curvature is the lateral surface of the stomach that interacts with the greater omentum to keep the stomach in place.
Incorrect. The rugae are folds of the mucosa and submucosa that can extend with the presence of food.

body.p: The gastric pits of the cardiac region of the stomach play an important role in:

input.choice: Secreting gastrin to help regulate digestion
Secreting mucus to protest the lining of the stomach

feedback.p: Incorrect. The gastric pits of the fundus and body secrete HCl for chemical digestion.
Incorrect. The gastric pits of the pyloric antrum, the fundus and the body secrete hormones.
Incorrect. White blood cells are responsible for secreting antibodies and they are not located in the stomach’s lumen.
Correct. The mucus secreting cells in the gastric pits of the cardiac region help supply the protective mucus to cover the stomach.

body.p: When a person walks into a store and smells the fresh baked goods what might this activate?

feedback.p: Correct. The cephalic phase occurs because of the smell, taste, sight or thought of food and prepares the stomach to receive food.
Incorrect. The gastric phase will not begin until food has entered the stomach.
Incorrect. The intestinal phase will not begin until the chime is leaving the stomach.

body.p: When the contents of the stomach are emptied into the duodenum, which is the first to exit?

feedback.p: Correct. Carbohydrate-rich foods are the quickest to leave the stomach.
Incorrect. High-protein foods exit more slowly than another type of food.
Incorrect. High triglyceride foods stay the longest in the stomach.

body.p: Which is the longest section of the small intestine?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The duodenum is the first and shortest portion of the small intestine.
Incorrect. The jejunum is the middle and second longest portion of the small intestine.
Correct. The ileum is the last and longest portion of the small intestine.
Incorrect. The cecum is part of the large intestine.

body.p: What feature is responsible for the wrinkled appearance of the colon?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The teniae coli are three bands of smooth muscle that make up the longitudinal muscle layer of the muscularis externa of the large intestine.
Correct. The haustra are pouches caused by the tonic contractions of the teniae coli that create the wrinkled appearance of the colon.
Incorrect. The epiploic appendages are fatty filled pouches of the peritoneum.
Incorrect. The omental appendices are are fatty filled pouches of the peritoneum.

body.p: What structures separate feces from flactus?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The mesocolons hold the transverse and sigmoid colons to the abdominal wall.
Incorrect. The external anal sphincter is a voluntary muscle that is opened during defecation.
Incorrect. The left colic flexure is where the transverse colon curves below the spleen.
Correct. The rectal valves are formed by a trio of internal folds that allow gas (flatus) out and retain the feces.

body.p: Most enteric bacteria are nonpathogenic commensals that cause no harm so long as they:

input.choice: Their components do not activate the dendritic cells.
They do not trigger an IgA antibody-mediated response.
They do not leave the lumen.

feedback.p: Incorrect. By activating the dendritic cells the body prevents the bacteria from leaving the lumen and causing a systemic reaction.
Incorrect. The HCl of the stomach has been neutralized by the small intestine. The human body relies on the
Incorrect. If they trigger an antibody mediated response the immune system will begin to act.
Correct. If they do not leave the lumen of the large intestine they will not cause an immune responce.

body.p: Which layer of the large intestine is responsible for helping to maintain water balance?

input.choice: None of the above all the water is absorbed in the small intestine

feedback.p: Incorrect. The lumen houses bacteria that can further digest some of chyme nutrients.
Correct. The mucosa layer absorbs water and helps to maintain water balance in the body.
Incorrect. The muscularis externa is responsible for the muscle movements that propel the feces.
Incorrect. The mucosa layer absorbs water and helps to maintain water balance in the body.

body.p: What is a by-product of bacterial digestion that occurs in the large intestine?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Carbohydrates are the main nutrient that the bacteria are digesting.
Incorrect. The chyme is the material from the small intestine that has a small amount of nutrients left to be digested.
Correct. Hydrogen sulfide is one of the gases that can be produced and lead to a foul odor.
Incorrect. Mucus is secreted by the goblet cells of the large intestine to help the movement of food and for protection. It is not a byproduct.

body.p: Which of the following statements is accurate?

input.choice: The external anal sphincter is under involuntary control of the parasympathetic nervous system
The internal anal sphincter is under voluntary control and can be used to delay defecation.
The Valsalva maneuver must be learned.
The defecation reflex must be learned.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The external sphincter is under voluntary control and can be used to delay defecation.
Incorrect. The internal sphincter is under involuntary control of the parasympathetic nervous system.
Correct. The valsalva maneuver is a set of voluntary actions that assist defecation and must be learned.
Incorrect. The defecation reflex is an involuntary occurrence and does not need to be learned.

body.p: Which pancreatic duct runs from the pancreas directly to the duodenum?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The duct of Wirsung is the main pancreatic duct that fuses with the common bile duct.
Incorrect. The hepatopancratic ampulla is after the pancreatic duct and the common bile duct fuse.
Incorrect. The main pancreatic duct that fuses with the common bile duct
Correct. This is another name for the accessory duct that runs directly to the duodenum.

body.p: Which of the following is not produced by the islets of Langerhans?

feedback.p: Correct. Pancreatic juice is secreted by the acini cells.
Incorrect. Insulin is a hormone produced by the islets.
Incorrect. Glucagon is a hormone produced by the islets.
Incorrect. Somatostatin is a hormone produced by the islets.

body.p: Which of the following is true of the pancreatic acini?

input.choice: They are regulated by blood glucose levels.
They are regulated by both hormones and parasympathetic nervous system.
They compose only 1% of the pancreas cells.
They are clusters of connective cells that secrete hormones.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The pancreatic islets can be stimulated by blood glucose levels.
Correct. These cells are regulated by hormones and the parasympathetic nervous system.
Incorrect. They compose 99% of the cells in the pancreas.
Incorrect. They are clusters of epithelial cells that secrete enzymes and bicarbonate rich juice.

body.p: Why are Zone 3 cells the first cells to die if circulation is disrupted?

input.choice: They are the first to receive toxic substances.
They are furthest from the portal triad branches.
They are the first to break down glycogen during fasting.

feedback.p: Incorrect. They do store energy as fat, but that is not why they are the first to die.
Incorrect. Cells in Zone 1 are the first to receive toxic substances.
Correct. They are the furthest from the portal triad which provides oxygen so if circulation is disrupted they will die first.
Incorrect. Cells in Zone 1 are the first to break down glycogen during fasting.

body.p: What vessel comes from the gastrointestinal tract directly to the liver bypassing general circulation?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The hepatic artery delivers oxygenated blood from the heart to the liver.
Incorrect. The hepatic triad contains the hepatic artery, hepatic portal vein and the bile duct.
Incorrect. The hepatic artery takes deoxygenated blood and wastes away from the liver.
Correct. The hepatic portal vein brings deoxygenate blood, nutrients, and toxins to the liver from the stomach.

body.p: Which structure collects the bile from the hepatocytes?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The ductules receive the bile from the bile canaliculi.
Correct. The bile canaliculi collect bile from the hepatocytes.
Incorrect. The bile ducts are formed from the bile ductules.
Incorrect. The hepatic ducts are formed from the bile ducts

body.p: Which two vessels bring blood to the liver?

input.choice: Hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein
Hepatic vein and hepatic portal vein

feedback.p: Incorrect. The hepatic vein takes deoxygenated blood from the liver and to the inferior vena cava.
Incorrect. The hepatic artery brings oxygenate blood to the liver, but the hepatic vein takes deoxygenated blood away from the liver.
Correct. The hepatic artery brings oxygenated blood from the heart and the hepatic portal vein brings nutrient rich blood from the GI tract to the liver.
Incorrect. The hepatic vein takes deoxygenated away from the liver. The hepatic portal vein brings nutrient rich blood to the liver from the GI tract

body.p: What is another name for the ligamentum teres?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The coronary ligament supporst the liver hanging from the diaphragm.
Incorrect. The ligamentum teres runs along the inferior border of the falciform ligament.
Correct. The round ligament is another name for the ligamentum teres.
Incorrect. The cruciate ligaments are paired ligaments in the knee.

body.p: What is the function of the gall bladder?

input.choice: Produces and stores protein digesting enzymes.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The bile is produced in the liver and only stored and concentrated in the gall bladder.
Correct. The function of the gall bladder is to concentrate and store the bile produced by the liver.
Incorrect. The gall bladder stores bile which will help emulsify fat but it is not a fat digesting enzyme.
Incorrect. The gall bladder stores bile which emulsifies fat and does not have protein digesting enzymes.

body.p: What are the major function(s) of the esophageal sphincter?

input.choice: Maintain the linear movement of the bolus
Compartmentalize the stomach from the small intestine
Control flow of bile from the liver.

feedback.p: Correct. In addition to protecting the esophagus from the gastric juice, this sphincter maintains the linear downward flow of the food.
Incorrect. The pyloric sphincter separates the stomach from the small intestine.
Incorrect. Defecation is controlled by the anal sphincter.
Incorrect. Bile is produced by the liver and stored in the gall bladder and released when needed to help break down fats

body.p: The goal of chemical and mechanical digestion is to convert food into substances that can be absorbed. Which of the following correctly describes nutrients not absorbed by active transport mechanisms?

input.choice: These fat-soluble vitamins are absorbed into the blood stream.
These proteins are absorbed into the lacteals.
These lipids are absorbed into the blood stream.
These lipids are absorbed into the lacteals.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Fat soluble vitamins cannot be absorbed by active transport into the blood and will be moved into the lacteals.
Incorrect. Lipids are transported to the lacteals the monomers of proteins will be absorbed into the blood stream and into the hepatic portal vein.
Incorrect. Lipids are hydrophobic and are not able to be transported directly to the blood.
Correct. Lipids are hydrophobic and so are not absorbed directly into the blood.

body.p: Which of the following is absorbed into the lacteals of the villi?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Glucose is water soluble and is absorbed into the capillary blood of the villi.
Incorrect. Amino acids are absorbed into the capillary blood of the villi.
Correct. Monoglycerides are hydrophobic and will be transported to the lacteals of the villi.
Incorrect. Nucleic acids are absorbed into the capillary blood of the villi.

body.p: Why do chylomicrons not enter the blood capillaries of the villi?

input.choice: The chylomicrons are too big to pass through the basement membrane.
The chylomicrons contain too many bile salts.
The golgi apparatus keeps them stored inside the cell.
The chylomicrons are found only in the chyme.

feedback.p: Correct. The chylomicrons are too bit to pass through the basement membrane so pass through the large pores of the lacteals.
Incorrect. The chylomicrons contain the water soluble lipoproteins.
Incorrect. The golgi apparatus processes the chylomicrons for release from the cell.
Incorrect. The chylomicrons are formed in the cells of the small intestine.

body.p: Which vitamin is not just ingested by the digestive system, but can be manufactured by our body cells?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Vitamin A is from colorful fruits and vegetables like carrots and enter through the digestive system.
Incorrect. Vitamin C is from fruit and vegetables such as citrus fruits and enter through the digestive system.
Correct. Vitamin D can be manufactured by our body as well as ingested. It requires that our skin is exposed to sunlight to produce.
Incorrect. Vitamin K can be produced by bacteria that reside in our intestine but not by our cells.

body.p: Which hormone secreted by the duodenal mucosa enhances the activity of CCK?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Serotonin regulates stomach contractions.
Incorrect. Somatostatin restricts all gastric secretions.
Incorrect. Gastrin provokes gastric emptying and relaxes the ileocecal valve
Correct. Secretin increases the production of pancreatic juices and enhances the activity of CCK.

body.p: GI reflex pathways can consist of what?

feedback.p: Partially correct. Parasympathetic nerves that increase GI secretion and are only part of the GI reflex pathway.
Partially correct. The sympathetic nerves which decrease GI secretions and are only part of the GI reflex pathway.
Incorrect. These different types of nerves are both part of the enteric nervous system and the GI reflex.
Correct. Both parasympathetic nerve fibers and sympathetic nerve fibers are part of the enteric nervous system and the GI reflex pathways.

body.p: Which of the following is a consequence of cholera?

input.choice: Formation of a rash on the skin

feedback.p: Incorrect. Water is not the only thing that the cholera toxin prevents from being reabsorbed in the large intestine.
Correct. The diarrhea caused by cholera toxin will cause the loss of both water and electrolytes.
Incorrect. A rash is not one of the symptoms caused by cholera.
Incorrect. Hemorrhoids are the result of inflamed or infected veins near the anus.
